qas.question: What type of organism has relatively gene dense chromosomes?
Regions of DNA that serve no obvious function are often found in what type of organism?
What is referred to as "junk DNA"?
What percentage of the human genome is made of protein coding DNA?
What percentage of bases in the human genome are expressed by protein coding DNA

context: Whereas the chromosomes of <a0_0>prokaryotes<a0_0/> are relatively gene-dense, those of <a1_0>eukaryotes<a1_0/> often contain regions of DNA that serve no obvious function. Simple single-celled eukaryotes have relatively small amounts of such DNA, whereas the genomes of complex multicellular organisms, including humans, contain an absolute majority of <a2_0>DNA without an identified function<a2_0/>. This DNA has often been referred to as "junk DNA". However, more recent analyses suggest that, although protein-coding DNA makes up <a3_0>barely 2%<a3_0/> of the human genome, <a4_0>about 80%<a4_0/> of the bases in the genome may be expressed, so the term "junk DNA" may be a misnomer.
